Trumbull County superintendents met with Health Commissioner Frank Migliozzi on Thursday to discuss Trumbull County's transition from Orange to Red on Gov. Mike DeWine's COVID 19 county map.

Because the status change was not the result of community spread, there is no immediate need for Lakeview Local Schools to change or revise our Return-To-School plans, according to the Trumbull County Combined Health District.

The Trumbull County Health District advised us that the rise in COVID 19 numbers is due to two specific outbreaks, both at long term health care facilities. It was also communicated that without these two outbreaks, the numbers in Trumbull County have been consistently trending in a positive direction.

As we continue to get updates, we will pass them along to you.

*East on Fowler St. to Cedar
*South on Cedar to Corriedale
*West on Corriedale to Wakefield
*Proceed through the K-8 Lot and back onto Wakefield
*North on Lakeview
*East on Natale and End at Lakeview High School

The Lakeview K-8 staff received training and "Stop The Bleed" buckets from University Hospitals. The buckets are placed in every classroom throughout the school.

Jason Smith, School Resource Officer at Lakeview Local Schools, gives us a look at what's inside the bucket.

"When putting this Stop The Bleed bucket together there was a lot of thought that went into this with the Fire Department as well as University Hospitals, taking lessons from other incidents that have happened in the schools in the country. Active shooter type situations and finding out what could have been used in those situations to save lives. Everything in here was taken out of those incidents and things that we can use. It's Lakeviews way of staying on top of things and to promote safety in the school buildings in those type of incidents," said Jason Smith, Lakeview Schools SRO.

post_text: Lakeview team's 'gourmet pizza' is on its way to Trumbull County! The Italian Philly Steak pizza developed by LMS students Ava Bacon, Lucas Easton, Isabella Isenberg & Will Kirila won the Best Gourmet Pizza category in March 24 Mahoning Valley Pizza Cook-off! The team developed its Italian Philly Steak pizza for Pizza’s Joe’s during the JA Innovation Challenge in December. The team was among 43 to participate in a Dec. 14 JA Innovation Challenge, an entrepreneurial workshop at Kent State University at Trumbull sponsored by the Trumbull County Educational Service Center in collaboration with Junior Achievement of Mahoning Valley. Students learned how to do market research, develop a new product and market it. Eight teams were chosen as semi-finalists to present their concepts to Pizza Joe’s.The Italian Philly will be available soon at Pizza Joe’s shops in Trumbull County.
